RIJU PRASAD SARMA AND OTHERS Appellants; Versus STATE OF ASSAM AND OTHERS Civil Appeals Nos. 3276-78 of2013t with Writ Petitions (C) Nos. 72 , 91 , 140 of 2012 and Respondents. SLPs (C) Nos. 18070-72 of2015 (CC Nos. 8089-91 of2012) , dec ided on July 7, 2015 A. Constitution of India - Arts. 25(2)(a) and 26(b) - To be read harmoniously - Freedom of religious denomination to manage its own religious affairs can be regulated by law contemplated by Art. 25(2), provided such law should not obliterate essential part of religious practice - Appointment of priest is a secular matter which can be regulated by law - But situation may be different where by virtue of custom, persons concerned (Bordeories of Kamakhya Temple) are themselves trustees as well as priests who have entrusted management of religious and secular activities to their elected representatives (Dolois) and thus element of appointment stood substituted by action of trustees themselves - However, in absence of any statute framed by State regulating affairs of the Temple, question of examining whether interference with custom governing appointment of Dolois amounted to obliteration of essential religious practices does not arise B. Constitution of India -Arts. 13(1) & (3), 25 and 26 - Custom based on religious faith and scriptures protected under Arts. 25 and 26 cannot be treated as void under Arts. 13(1) & (3) - Religious freedom can be curtailed for carrying out reforms and changes by State by enacting law to the extent permissible under Art. 25(2), which is reformist in nature - Art. 25(2) gives scope to State to study and understand all relevant issues before undertaking reforms or changes in respect of matters relating to religion which are sensitive C. Constitution of India - Arts. 12, 32, 226, 13, 14, 25 and 26 - Definition of "the State" under Art. 12 - Whether courts included - Maintainability of writ petition against private parties solely on ground that not entertaining the same would amount to perpetuating discrimination by court which is part of "the State" under Art. 12 - Omission of judiciary, g held, not conclusive of its exclusion from the definition of "the State" under Art. 12 - While acting on judicial side, courts do not fall within the definition but while acting in administrative capacity, they are covered by the definition - Even if there appears to be any discrimination between private parties by operation of long standing religious custom, court cannot be obligated to entertain writ petition filed by aggrieved party on untenable h t From the Judgment and Order dated 25-10-2011 in WAs Nos. 311-12 of 2004 and WP (C) No. 923 of2005 of the Division Bench of the Gauhati High Court ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. (1) r/w cl. (3) of Art. 13 - Plea that while acting in judicial capacity judiciary acts as "State" and as such must entertain writ petition against private parties only because matter is brought before court, has no merit - Words and Phrases - "State" The families of the priests of the main temple i.e. Maa Kamakhya Temple are called "Bordeories". The families of the priests of the subsidiary temples are known as "Deuris". The head priest is called the "Doloi". Rule 3 of the Assam State Acquisition of Lands Belonging to Religious or Charitable Institution of Public Nature (Election of Managing Committee of Sri Sri Maa Kamakhya Temple) Rules, 2012 provides two electoral colleges, one for the election to the post of ex-officio Secretary, restricted to Bordeories of Kamakhya Temple and the other for the election of five members of the Managing Committee, consisting of "devotees". Rule 6 requires the Deputy Commissioner to treat the list of electors already prepared by the Bordeories and published in connection with the election of Dolois as the electoral rolls for the election of ex-officio Secretary. Claims and objections on the basis of such tentative electoral rolls are to be entertained from the Bordeories only. The traditional list of electors for election of Dolois includes only adult male Bordeories and hence women members of Bordeori families did not find place in the draft electoral rolls which were published under the Rules. Deuries and priests of other devalayas known as Nanan Devalayas are also not included in this electoral roll because for election to the post of ex-officio Secretary only the Bordeories are qualified to be in the electoral college and be a candidate also. The plea of the petitioners was that no doubt fundamental rights under Articles 14 and 15 unlike rights such as against untouchability are guaranteed only against State action and not against private customs or practices but judiciary is as much a part of State as the executive and the legislature and hence it cannot permit perpetuation of discrimination in violation of Article 14, particularly in view of Article 13(1) which mandates that all pre-Constitution laws in the territory of India to the extent they are inconsistent with the provisions of Part III of the Constitution shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void. It is the case of the petitioners that the custom relating to election of the Dolois to the extent it violates Article 14, must be treated as void and the Supreme Court should grant relief to the women members of Bordeori families and also to the Deuries by ordering for inclusion of their names in the electoral college. Rejecting the contention, the Supreme Court Held: Article 25(2)(a) and Article 26(b) guaranteeing the right to every religious denomination to manage its own affairs in matters of religion are subject to and can be controlled by a law contemplated under Article 25(2)(b) as both the Articles are required to be read harmoniously. Social reforms or the need for regulations contemplated by Article 25(2) cannot obliterate essential religious practices or their performances and what would constitute the essential part of a religion can be ascertained with reference to the doctrine of that religion itself. State of Mysore, AIR 1958 SC 255 : 1958 SCR 895, relied on The matter of appointment of a competent priest is a secular matter and therefore can be regulated by a State action. However, the situation may be different and more complicated if, like in the present case, the Bordeories are the trustees as well as the priest and the management of religious and secular activities have been entrusted by the Bordeories themselves to their elected representatives, the Dolois. The element of appointment stands substituted by the action of the trustees themselves performing the necessary rituals. This aspect need not be pursued any further because there is no statute framed by the State so far to regulate even the secular affairs of the Temple. Only when such State action takes place, there may arise an occasion to examine the related issues as to whether interference with the custom governing appointment of Dolois would amount to regulating only the secular affairs of the Temple or it shall obliterate the essential religious practices of the institution. (Para 65) Seshammal V, State ofT.N., (1972) 2 sec 11, distinguished Article 13(1) applies only to such pre-Constitution laws including customs which are inconsistent with the provisions of Part III of the Constitution and not to such religious customs and personal laws which are protected by the fundamental rights such as Articles 25 and 26. In other words, religious beliefs, customs and practices based upon religious faith and scriptures cannot be treated to be void. Religious freedoms protected by Articles 25 and 26 can be curtailed only by law made by a competent legislature to the permissible extent. The court can surely examine and strike down a State action or law on the grounds of Articles 14 and 15. But in a pluralist society as existing in India, the task of carrying out reforms affecting religious beliefs has to be left in the hands of the State. This line of thinking is supported by Article 25(2) which is clearly reformist in nature. It also provides scope for the State to study and understand all the relevant issues before undertaking the required changes and reforms in an area relating to religion which shall always be sensitive. (Para 67) Pradeep Kumar Biswas v. Indian Institute of Chemical Biology, (2002) 5 SCC 111 : 2002 SCC (L&S) 633; Naresh Shridhar Mirajkar v. State of Maharashtra, AIR 1967 SC 1: (1966) 3 SCR 744; Triveniben v. State of Gujarat, (1989) 1 SCC 678: 1989 SCC (Cri) 248; Poonam V. Sumit Tanwar, (2010) 4 sec 460 : (2010) 2 sec (Civ) 177, relied on While performing judicial functions stricto sensu, the Judiciary cannot and should not be equated with other organs of State-the Executive and the Legislature. This also fits in harmony with the concept of separation of powers and spares the judiciary or the courts to dispassionately examine the constitutionality of State action allegedly curbing or curtailing the fundamental rights including those under Articles 25 and 26 of the Constitution. Therefore, while acting on the judicial side the courts are not included in the definition of "the State". Only when they deal with their employees or act in other matters purely in administrative capacity, the courts may fall within the definition of the State for attracting writ jurisdiction against their administrative actions only. Such a contextual interpretation must be preferred because it shall promote justice, especially through impartial adjudication in matters of protection of fundamental rights governed by Part III of the Constitution. (Paras 66 and 68) Harjinder Singh v. Punjab State Warehousing Co rpn., (2010) 3 SCC 192 : (2010) 1 SCC (L&S) 1146; Indira Nehru Gandhi v. Raj Narain, 1975 Supp SCC 1, explained and distinguished If the submission is accepted that by simply hearing a writ petition the Court becomes a party with same duties and responsibilities as the State, then the rights which can be claimed only against the State can also be claimed against all private parties because judiciary has to hear and decide almost all cases. Such plea is required to be noticed only for rejection otherwise all disputes against private persons will have to be treated as a dispute against the State also, because it is primary responsibility of the judiciary to hear and adjudicate all disputes. The judicial forum will then lose its impartiality because the petitioners, like in the present case, will make a demand that the Court itself should act as the State and deliver all reliefs in a dispute where the executive or the legislature is not at all involved as a party. In a catena of judgments it has been held that writ petitions will not be entertained against purely private parties. Further, elaborate tests have been laid down for finding out when an authority can be treated to be the State for the purposes of Part III of the Constitution. Therefore, there is no merit in the contention that while acting in judicial capacity the judiciary acts as the State and hence it must, as a corollary, entertain a writ petition against purely private parties only because the matter has been brought before the Court. Constitution of India - Arts. 226 and 32 - Writ petition for enforcement of right (statutory, fundamental or constitutional), which is in dispute between parties - Writ court can enforce the right claimed only after coming to definite conclusion that factual foundation has been laid down and established for claiming the same - Issues and facts, having great public impact, cannot be decided by writ court on basis of oath of parties Held: It may not always be safe for a writ court to decide issues and facts having great impact on the general public or a large part of it only on the basis of oath against oath. Where the right is admitted and well established, the Writ Court will not hesitate in implementing such a right especially a fundamental right. But enforcement of established rights is a different matter than the establishment of the right itself. When there is a serious dispute between two private parties as to the expertise, experience and qualification for a particular job, the prime task before the Court is first to analyse the facts for coming to a definite conclusion whether the right stands established and only when the answer is in affirmative, the Court may have no difficulty in enforcing such an established right, whether statutory, fundamental or constitutional. In the present case, it is indeed difficult for the Supreme Court to come to a definite conclusion that the petitioners' claim to equality for the purpose at hand is well established. As all the institutions in the State have both Dearies and Bordeories, it would be inevitable to get the ex-officio Secretary elected either by the Dearies or the Bordeories , whosoever may be managing the institution concerned. (Para 43) The terms "Dearies" and "Bordeories" are not defined under the Act. Clearly the task of defining or explaining the terms "Dearies" or "Bordeories" in the context of a particular institution has been left to be done by making of rules. The 2012 Rules seek to provide for a Managing Committee in terms of Section 25-A only for the Temple of Sri Sri Maa Kamakhya. Under statutory powers , the State Government in the context of this particular institution has recognised only Bordeories by referring to the traditional Bordeori Samaj of the Temple. The other devotees, shebaits and Deories, if any, have been included in the category of "devotee" with a right to participate in the election of other five members of the Managing Committee. Trusts and Trustees - Religious and Charitable Endowments and Trusts - Assam State Acquisition of Lands Belonging to Religious or Charitable Institution of Public Nature (Election of Managing Committee of Sri Sri Maa Kamakhya Temple) Rules, 2012 - Rr. 2, 3 and 6 - Constitutionality - Discrimination alleged - R. 3 providing for two electoral colleges, one for election to post of ex-officio Secretary, restricted to Bordeories (devotees constituting traditional Bordeori Samaj of priests) of Kamakhya Temple and another for election of five members of Managing Committee, consisting of "devotees" (all worshippers, priests, shebaits or persons associated with the Temple) - In electoral rolls notified under R. 6, for election of Dolois (priests), only adult male Bordeories were included and female members of Bordeori families as also Dolois of N anan Devalayas (both male and female) were excluded - Categorical stand taken by State that Rules do not debar female members of Bordeori families and that it has no objection in allowing claims by female members for inclusion of their names in electoral rolls - Contention raised by the Dolois of N anan Devalayas, both male and female as well as female members of the Bordeori families that their exclusion by virtue of the Rules notified by the State Government is unconstitutional being violative of Art. 14 of the Constitution - Held, in view of distinct status and exclusive monopoly of Bordeori families in matters of religious as well as secular management of the Temple, claim of equality on behalf of Dearies associated with N anan Devalayas or even Kamakhya Temple has no merit - Further, in view of such clear and categorical distinction, State cannot be blamed for creating two electoral colleges and confining electoral rolls for ex-officio Secretary only to members of Bordeori families including females - Fair treatment to others interested in the Temple assured by permitting "devotees" to elect five members of Managing Committee - Hence challenge to the Rules on ground of violation of Art. 14 of the Constitution must fail - But in a pluralist society as existing in India, the task of carrying out reforms affecting religious beliefs has to be left in the hands of the State. This line of thinking is supported by Article 25(2) which is clearly reformist in nature. It also provides scope for the State to study and understand all the relevant issues before undertaking the required changes and reforms in an area relating to religion which shall always be sensitive. While performing judicial functions stricto sensu, the Judiciary cannot and should not be equated with other organs of State-the Executive and the Legislature. This also fits in harmony with the concept of separation of powers and spares the judiciary or the courts to dispassionately examine the constitutionality of State action allegedly curbing or curtailing the fundamental rights including those under Articles 25 and 26. 67.
